title: Deactivate ActiveX
description: ActiveX is barley used nowadays, but Microsoft browsers have it enabled by default. It acts as a middleware between Java and Flash applications and your PC. But it is commonly used for malicious sites to run scripts directly on your PC. See this article for more details

title: Disable Flash
description: Adobe Flash has been around since the dawn of the internet, however it has been falling in popularity for a while. It brings with it many unpatched vulnerabilities (a few of which you can read about here). See this guide, on how to disable Flash player, or this guide for more details on how dangerous it can be

title: Block Trackers
description: Consider installing a browser extension, such as Privacy Badger, to stop advertisers from secretly tracking you

title: Block scripts from bad origin
description: Use an extension such as uBlock Origin, to block anything being loaded from an external or unverified origin

title: Force HTTPS only traffic
description: Ensure that you only use websites through https. It’s recommended to use an extension such as HTTPS Everywhere, to force all sites to load securely

title: Only use trusted browser addons and extensions
description: Both Firefox and Chrome webstore allow you to check what permissions access rights an extension requires before you install it. Check the reviews. Only install extensions you really need.

title: Always keep your browser up-to-date
description: Browser vulnerabilities are constantly being discovered and patched, so it’s important to keep it up to date, to avoid a zero-day exploit

title: Use a private search engine
description: Take a look at DuckDuckGo or StartPage. Neither store cookies or cache anything

title: Consider a privacy browser
description: Google openly collects usage data on Chrome usage. There are several privacy browsers out there which minimise the amount of data collected. Have a look at Brave Browser, Yandex, or Comodo. As a more extreme choice, consider Tor

title: Disable JavaScript
description: Many modern web apps, are JavaScript based, so disabling it will greatly reduce your browsing experience. But if you really want to go all out, then it will reduce your attack surface. Read more about the growing risk of JavaScript malware
